intro: Uncinia ecuadorensis, commonly known as the Ecuadorian hookweed, is a perennial herb native to the Andean regions of Ecuador. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, greenish-yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories and rocky slopes. Its leaves are lance-shaped with hairy surfaces, and it produces small, clustered fruits that are adapted for wind dispersal. Uncinia ecuadorensis is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations in its native habitat.
